title: Crypto Safety 101
description: Learn how to secure your crypto wallet, verify legitimate projects, and avoid the most common crypto scams.

lessons.title: Understanding Wallet Security
lessons.content:
Your crypto wallet is your bank account. Here's how to keep it safe:

1. **Never share your seed phrase** — No legitimate service, exchange, or support team will ever ask for your seed phrase. Period. If someone asks for it, it's a scam.

2. **Use a hardware wallet** — For any significant holdings, use a hardware wallet like Ledger or Trezor. These keep your private keys offline and safe from hackers.

3. **Enable 2FA everywhere** — Use authenticator apps (Google Authenticator, Authy), NOT SMS-based 2FA which can be SIM-swapped.

4. **Bookmark your exchanges** — Never click links from emails or DMs. Always type the URL or use bookmarks.

5. **Use a dedicated browser** — Keep a separate browser with no extensions for crypto activity.

lessons.title: Verifying Projects Before Investing
lessons.content:
Before putting money into any crypto project, check these:

1. **Team verification** — Are the team members real people with verifiable backgrounds? Check LinkedIn, search their names.

2. **Smart contract audit** — Has the contract been audited by reputable firms like CertiK or Trail of Bits? Is it verified on Etherscan?

3. **Liquidity check** — Is liquidity locked? For how long? Use tools like DexTools or DexScreener.

4. **Community analysis** — Is the community organic or full of bots? Check Twitter followers for engagement ratio.

5. **Token Sniffer** — Run the token through Token Sniffer or RugDoc for automated red flag detection.

lessons.title: Common Crypto Scams to Avoid
lessons.content:
Here are the most common crypto scams:

1. **Rug Pulls** — Developers create a token, hype it up, then drain the liquidity and disappear with your money.

2. **Pump and Dumps** — Coordinated buying to inflate price, then selling at the top while you hold the bag.

3. **Fake Airdrops** — 'Connect your wallet to claim free tokens' — but the smart contract drains your wallet instead.

4. **Phishing Sites** — Fake exchange or DeFi sites that look identical to real ones but steal your credentials.

5. **Double Your Crypto** — ALWAYS a scam. No one will double your crypto. Ever.

title: Phishing Defense
description: Learn to spot fake emails, websites, and messages before they steal your information or money.

lessons.title: Spotting Fake Emails
lessons.content:
Phishing emails are getting more sophisticated. Here's how to spot them:

1. **Check the sender address** — Look carefully. paypa1.com is NOT paypal.com. amaz0n-support.com is NOT amazon.com.

2. **Hover over links** — Before clicking any link, hover over it to see the actual URL. If it doesn't match the expected domain, don't click.

3. **Look for urgency** — 'Your account will be suspended in 24 hours!' is a classic pressure tactic.

4. **Check for personalization** — Legitimate companies use your name. 'Dear Customer' or 'Dear User' is suspicious.

5. **Grammar and spelling** — While improving, many phishing emails still have telltale errors.

lessons.title: Identifying Fake Websites
lessons.content:
Fake websites can look identical to real ones:

1. **Check the URL carefully** — Look for misspellings, extra characters, or wrong TLDs (paypal.com.evil.com).

2. **Look for HTTPS** — But remember, HTTPS alone doesn't mean a site is safe. Scammers use HTTPS too.

3. **Check the domain age** — Use WHOIS lookup. Legitimate sites have been around for years.

4. **Use browser bookmarks** — Bookmark your bank, exchange, and important sites. Always use bookmarks.

5. **Enable browser warnings** — Keep your browser's safe browsing features enabled.

lessons.title: Protecting Yourself
lessons.content:
Prevention is better than cure:

1. **Use a password manager** — 1Password, Bitwarden, or similar. Unique passwords for every site.

2. **Enable 2FA** — On every important account. Use authenticator apps, not SMS.

3. **Don't click links in emails** — Go directly to the website instead.

4. **Report phishing** — Forward phishing emails to the company being impersonated and to reportfraud.ftc.gov.

5. **Keep software updated** — Browsers, operating systems, and apps. Updates patch security vulnerabilities.

title: Romance Scam Red Flags
description: Recognize pig butchering, catfishing, and romance scam patterns before you lose money or your heart.

lessons.title: How Romance Scams Work
lessons.content:
Romance scams follow a predictable pattern:

1. **Contact** — They reach out on dating apps, social media, or even LinkedIn. Profile pictures are stolen from real people.

2. **Love Bombing** — They shower you with attention, compliments, and declarations of love very quickly.

3. **The Story** — They claim to be military, doctors, engineers working overseas — anything to explain why they can't meet in person.

4. **The Ask** — After building emotional connection, they need money for an emergency, a plane ticket, medical bills, or a 'sure thing' investment.

5. **Escalation** — The requests get bigger. They may introduce 'pig butchering' — convincing you to invest in fake crypto platforms.

lessons.title: Red Flags to Watch For
lessons.content:
Watch for these warning signs:

1. **They can never video call** — Or if they do, the 'camera is broken.' They avoid anything that proves their identity.

2. **Too perfect, too fast** — They say everything you want to hear. The relationship moves unrealistically fast.

3. **Asks for money** — Anyone who asks for money online before meeting in person is likely a scammer.

4. **Inconsistent story** — Details change. Time zones don't match up. Their English skill varies between messages.

5. **They're overseas** — They claim to be deployed, working on an oil rig, or stuck in another country.

lessons.title: What To Do If You Suspect a Scam
lessons.content:
If something feels off, trust your gut:

1. **Reverse image search** — Upload their profile picture to Google Images or TinEye. Scammers use stolen photos.

2. **Ask to video call** — Insist on a video call. If they refuse or make excuses repeatedly, it's likely a scam.

3. **Never send money** — No matter the story, never send money to someone you haven't met in person.

4. **Talk to someone** — Tell a friend or family member about the relationship. Outside perspective helps.

5. **Report it** — Report the profile to the dating app or social media platform, and to the FTC.

title: Investment Scam Detection
description: Learn to identify Ponzi schemes, pyramid schemes, and too-good-to-be-true investment opportunities.

lessons.title: Ponzi Schemes Explained
lessons.content:
A Ponzi scheme pays old investors with new investors' money:

1. **Consistent returns** — They promise steady, above-market returns (10%+ monthly is always a red flag).

2. **No real investment** — There's no actual product, trade, or investment. Your money goes to pay earlier investors.

3. **Recruitment pressure** — They push you to bring in friends and family, because they need new money to pay you.

4. **Difficulty withdrawing** — When you try to take profits, there are delays, fees, or minimum hold periods.

5. **Famous examples** — Bernie Madoff ($65B), BitConnect ($2.6B), OneCoin ($4B+).

lessons.title: Pyramid & MLM Warning Signs
lessons.content:
Pyramid schemes disguised as businesses:

1. **Recruitment > Sales** — If making money requires recruiting others rather than selling a real product, it's a pyramid.

2. **Inventory loading** — Required to buy large amounts of product upfront.

3. **Income disclosure** — Look at the company's income disclosure statement. Usually 99% of participants lose money.

4. **Pay to play** — Paying to join or paying monthly fees for the right to sell.

5. **Complex compensation plans** — If you need a degree in math to understand how you get paid, that's by design.

lessons.title: Due Diligence Checklist
lessons.content:
Before investing in anything:

1. **Is the company registered?** — Check with the SEC (EDGAR), FINRA BrokerCheck, or your state regulator.

2. **Can you verify returns?** — Ask for audited financial statements from a reputable accounting firm.

3. **Understand the business model** — If you can't explain how the investment makes money in simple terms, don't invest.

4. **Check for complaints** — Search '[company name] scam' or '[company name] complaints.'

5. **Is it too good to be true?** — The S&P 500 averages ~10% annually. Anything promising significantly more is likely a scam.

title: Online Shopping Safety
description: Spot fake stores, review fraud, and protect yourself when shopping online.

lessons.title: Identifying Fake Online Stores
lessons.content:
Fake stores steal your money and credit card info:

1. **Too-cheap prices** — If designer goods are 80% off, it's fake. No one sells $500 shoes for $50.

2. **Check the domain** — New domains (registered recently), misspelled brand names, and unusual TLDs are red flags.

3. **Contact info** — Legitimate stores have real phone numbers, physical addresses, and responsive customer service.

4. **Payment methods** — If they only accept wire transfer, crypto, or gift cards — it's a scam. Legitimate stores accept credit cards.

5. **Social proof** — Check for reviews outside the website. Search '[store name] review' or '[store name] scam.'

lessons.title: Spotting Fake Reviews
lessons.content:
Reviews are easily manipulated:

1. **Review timing** — Many 5-star reviews in a short period is suspicious. Organic reviews come in gradually.

2. **Generic language** — 'Great product! Arrived on time! Love it!' with no specific details.

3. **Reviewer profiles** — Click on reviewers. If they've reviewed dozens of unrelated products in one week, they're fake.

4. **Use tools** — Fakespot and ReviewMeta analyze Amazon review authenticity.

5. **Look for negative reviews** — Genuine products have some negative reviews. All 5-stars is suspicious.

lessons.title: Safe Shopping Practices
lessons.content:
Protect yourself when shopping online:

1. **Use credit cards** — Credit cards offer dispute protection. Debit cards don't. Never use wire transfers.

2. **Check for HTTPS** — But remember, HTTPS alone doesn't mean a site is safe.

3. **Use PayPal or Apple Pay** — These add a layer of protection between your card and the merchant.

4. **Monitor your statements** — Check credit card statements regularly for unauthorized charges.

5. **Be skeptical of social media ads** — Many scam stores run polished Instagram and Facebook ads.

title: Phone Scam Survival
description: Recognize and defend against tech support, IRS, grandparent, and other phone scams.

lessons.title: Common Phone Scam Types
lessons.content:
Phone scammers use these tactics:

1. **Tech support scams** — 'Your computer has a virus!' They want remote access to steal your data or install malware.

2. **IRS/Tax scams** — 'You owe back taxes and will be arrested!' The real IRS never calls demanding immediate payment.

3. **Grandparent scams** — 'Grandma, I'm in jail and need bail money!' They target elderly people by impersonating grandchildren.

4. **Bank fraud scams** — 'We detected suspicious activity.' They ask you to 'verify' your account info, which they then steal.

5. **Prize/lottery scams** — 'You've won! Just pay the processing fee.' You didn't win anything.

lessons.title: How To Respond
lessons.content:
When you get a suspicious call:

1. **Don't trust caller ID** — Scammers spoof real phone numbers. Your caller ID might show 'IRS' or your bank's number.

2. **Hang up and call back** — If a bank or agency calls, hang up and call the number on their official website.

3. **Never give remote access** — No legitimate company will cold-call you and ask for remote access to your computer.

4. **Don't pay with gift cards** — No legitimate organization accepts payment in gift cards, crypto, or wire transfers.

5. **Take your time** — Scammers create urgency. A legitimate issue can wait for you to verify.

lessons.title: Protecting Yourself and Others
lessons.content:
Prevention and protection:

1. **Register on Do Not Call list** — Register your number at donotcall.gov. It won't stop all calls but reduces legitimate telemarketing.

2. **Use call blocking** — Enable spam call filtering on your phone. Most carriers offer free spam blocking.

3. **Talk to elderly family members** — Educate them about common scams. They're the most targeted demographic.

4. **Report scam calls** — Report to the FTC at reportfraud.ftc.gov.

5. **Watch scam baiting videos** — Channels like Kitboga, Jim Browning, and ScammerPayback show how these scams work in real time.
